awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using Controlled Aerosol Perturbations to Improve Understanding of Cloud Responses for Climate
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The representation of clouds and cloud processes in climate prediction models contributes to major uncertainties in climate simulations.  An incomplete understanding of how aerosol-cloud-precipitation interactions affect cloud properties in the models is a major contributor to this uncertainty.   One feature that is particularly challenging is the model representation of the formation of precipitation in relatively shallow clouds that can have a substantial impact on energy and water budgets.  Aerosol variability in the atmosphere can modify this process.  In some cases increased concentrations of smaller aerosol particles (for example due to pollution) may suppress precipitation.  But in contrast a few larger aerosols (for example salt particles from sea spray) can enhance and accelerate the initiation and intensity of precipitation in nature. But establishing cause- and-effect involving aerosol-precipitation connections is difficult to establish, since the concentrations of large nuclei are very small and measuring these particle concentrations are difficult.  Further the precipitation process can also depend on other processes that may be varying at the same time. To minimize some of these uncertainties and to constrain the possible responses, a technique for artificially introducing salt particles into low-level marine stratus cloud was developed and demonstrated.  This technique—artificial cloud seeding for science—provides a means to study cause-and-effect for the enhancement of precipitation processes in clouds by large soluble aerosols (giant cloud condensation nuclei).   Flights made with an instrumented aircraft flown off the coast of California were used to establish a technique for dispersing salt particles in clouds and then measuring the effects that the addition of giant cloud condensation nuclei have on the precipitation process.  In this case salt crystals milled to a size of about 3-5 microns were dispersed and the effects were detected.  The cloud seeding for science experiments performed under this grant have established the validity of this technique and opened the way for future studies to establish cause and effect relationships among aerosols and precipitation initiation in shallow clouds and to improve the treatment of cloud processes in climate prediction models.
